title-group.article-title: Neuronal Autophagy as a Mediator of Life and Death
title-group.subtitle: Contrasting Roles in Chronic Neurodegenerative and Acute Neural Disorders

abstract.p: Autophagy is a cellular mechanism for degrading proteins and organelles. It was first described as a physiological process essential for cellular health and survival, and this is its role in most cells. However, it can also be a mediator of cell death, either by the triggering of apoptosis or by an independent “autophagic” cell death mechanism. This duality is important in the central nervous system, where the activation of autophagy has recently been shown to be protective in certain chronic neurodegenerative diseases but deleterious in acute neural disorders such as stroke and hypoxic/ischemic injury. The authors here discuss these distinct roles of autophagy in the nervous system with a focus on the role of autophagy in mediating neuronal death. The development of new therapeutic strategies based on the manipulation of autophagy will need to take into account these opposing roles of autophagy.

body.p: Autophagy is the process of autodigesting cellular contents in lysosomes. There are three kinds: microautophagy, chaperone-mediated autophagy, and the main type, macroautophagy (Fig. 1) (Cuervo 2004). In this review, we focus on macroautophagy (referred to here simply as autophagy), emphasizing its roles in the survival or death of neurons. Although the term autophagy was coined more than 40 years ago, it was neglected for many years but has recently become a subject of intense interest because of the availability of molecular methodologies for inhibiting it. Autophagy plays a physiological role important for cellular growth and differentiation, especially for maintaining cellular homeostasis, which requires the continual turnover of nonfunctional proteins and organelles. There are two main pathways for this turnover. Of these, the ubiquitin-proteasome system is the most important for degrading short-lived proteins, whereas autophagy is the main mechanism for catabolizing long-lived proteins and organelles. Autophagy can also be a survival response in situations of stress, allowing the elimination of toxic metabolites, intracellular pathogens, and damaged proteins and organelles and providing energy and amino acids necessary for vital functions during cellular starvation. However, the induction of excessive (in some sense) autophagy can also lead to cell death. Autophagy plays this paradoxical role in many cell types, including neurons.

caption.p: Types of autophagy. There are three types of autophagy. Microautophagy involves the direct sequestration of a part of the cytosol by the membrane of a lysosome. Chaperone-mediated autophagy is specific for proteins carrying a precise sequence of five amino acids (KFERQ). These proteins are taken up by a complex, formed by the chaperone protein (hsc70) and co-chaperones (hip, hop, hsp40, hsp90, and bag1), that directs them to a lysosome where they are recognized by a receptor associated with the lysosomal membrane (LAMP-2A) that recognizes them and causes their translocation to the lysosomal interior. Finally, macroautophagy, which is the least selective type of autophagy, involves the sequestration of an entire region of cytosol containing organelles and proteins in a two-membraned vesicle called an autophagosome. The origin of these membranes is not entirely clear, but the process appears to involve the elongation of a membranous structure called the “pre-autophagosome.” The autophagosome then merges with the lysosome to form an autolysosome in which the ingested constituents are degraded by the lysosomal enzymes. Thus, macroautophagy generates nucleotides, amino acids, and free fatty acids that can be reused for the synthesis of new macromolecules and energy (ATP).

sec.title: Molecular Mechanisms of Macroautophagy
sec.p: Autophagy was first described in mammalian cells, but its most detailed molecular dissection was in yeast, leading to the discovery of more than 30 genes, designated “atg” for “autophagy-related genes,” that are strongly conserved from yeast to mammals. The above report is simplified, but more detailed accounts are available (He and Klionsky 2009; Glick and others 2010; Mehrpour and others 2010).

The biogenesis of autophagosomes begins with the formation of a pre-autophagosome (or phagophore), a membranous structure containing all the proteins necessary for the creation of an autophagosome, assembled from membranes of preexisting organelles (endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi, mitochondria, plasma membrane) (Axe and others 2008; Hayashi-Nishino and others 2009; Hailey and others 2010; Hamasaki and Yoshimori 2010; Ravikumar and others 2010) (Fig. 1). This pre-autophagosome undergoes a phase of elongation, then incurvation and end-to-end fusion, to sequester the cytoplasmic constituents to be degraded in the resulting double-membraned autophagosome. As an essential physiological process, autophagy is highly regulated, being held at a low basal level in normal conditions but up-regulated when required. The protein kinase mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin) is a central actor at the crossroads of different pathways regulating autophagy (Fig. 2) (Carrera 2004; Pattingre and others 2008). The PI3K-I (phosphoinisitol 3 kinase class I)–AKT/PKB (activator) or AMPK (inhibitor) pathways are indirectly involved in mTOR activity and autophagy regulation. Indeed, the inhibition of mTOR induces the activation of autophagy—for example, following nutrient starvation (the best-known stimulus of autophagy)—enabling the cell to produce metabolites necessary for ATP production and protein synthesis. However, an autophagy induction independent of mTOR can also occur (Sarkar and others 2009).

caption.p: Main molecular mechanisms involved in the formation of the autophagosome and in the regulation of autophagy. Different conditions are known to induce autophagy, including hypoxia, reactive oxygen species (ROS) formation, protein aggregation, and, above all, starvation. In fact, decreases in amino acids (aa), in ATP, in insulin, or in growth factor lead to induction of autophagy via the inhibition of mTOR, a central negative regulator of autophagy. mTOR inhibition allows ULK1/2 complex activity, which increases autophagy induction. The process starts with the isolation of a membrane from preexisting organelles such as the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the trans-Golgi network (TGN). The PI3K-III/Beclin 1 complex plays a crucial role in the nucleation phase. The first step of vesicle nucleation requires the activation of PI3K-III following the formation of a complex containing Atg14L, whereas membrane curvature involves a complex with UVRAG (UV irradiation resistance-associated gene). The elongation phase depends on the combined action of the Atg12-Atg5 and PE-Atg8/LC3 conjugation complexes. The pre-autophagosome elongates, envelops constituents to be degraded, and then closes to form an autophagosome, which usually has a double membrane. LC3-II is the only Atg protein known to be present in autophagosomes (linked to the inner membrane), all the others being removed and recycled. PE = phosphatidylethanolamine.

sec.p: Autophagy depends on the interaction of different complexes in which each Atg protein has one or several roles to play (Mehrpour and others 2010; Yang Z and Klionsky 2010). The most important complexes are the following (Fig. 2):

sec.title: ULK1-2 complex
sec.p: In mammalian cells, ULK1/2 (Unc-51-like kinase 1 and 2, Atg1 homologues) forms a stable complex with FIP200 (focal adhesion kinase family-interacting protein 200 kD, Atg17 homologue) and mAtg13 (mammalian Atg13). When mTOR is activated, it links to ULK1-2 complex to inhibit its action. In autophagic conditions, mTOR is inhibited and detaches from the complex, leading to activation of mATG13 and FIP200 (Hara and others 2008). ULK1/2 complex is located on pre-autophagosomal membranes and is thus involved in the induction of autophagy notably by recruiting mAtg9 (Jung and others 2009; Hosokawa and others 2009).

sec.title: PI3KIII–Beclin 1 complex
sec.p: The PI3K-III (Vps34 homologue) and Beclin 1 (Atg6 homologue) can form two different complexes involving either Atg14L (Atg14-like protein or Barkor) or UVRAG (UV irradiation resistance-associated gene) (Liang and others 2008; Sun and others 2008; Itakura and others 2008). Both complexes contribute to the first stage of autophagosome formation. The Atg14L complex plays a role in the recruitment of the complexes Atg12-Atg5 and PE-Atg8/LC3 (see below) at the level of the pre-autophagosomal membrane. UVRAG complex permits the incurvation of the pre-autophagosome (Takahashi and others 2009).

sec.title: LC3-PE conjugate
sec.p: Atg8 has several homologues in mammals: GABARAP (γ-aminobutyric acid type A receptor-associated protein), GATE-16 (Golgi-associated ATPase enhancer of 16 kDa), mAtg8L, and the most studied, LC3 (microtubule-associated protein 1 light chain 3, A and B). Cytosolic LC3 is first synthesized as a pro-LC3, proteolytically converted to LC3-I form, and finally conjugated to a phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), which is an abundant phospholipid in membranes. As a result, LC3 is incorporated into a pre-autophagosomal membrane (Geng and Klionsky 2008). This posttranscriptional form, LC3-II, seems to be involved in the elongation process and the closure of the autophagosome (Nakatogawa and others 2007).

sec.title: Atg12-Atg5 conjugate
sec.p: Atg12 and Atg5 form a complex that binds Atg16L (homologue of Atg16) via Atg5. By oligomerization, Atg16L forms larger complexes linked to the pre-autophagosomal membrane that are essential for the elongation process (Mizushima and others 2003). The presence of this complex is also indispensable for recruitment of the LC3-PE conjugate (Longatti and Tooze 2009).

sec.title: mAtg9 complex
sec.p: mAtg9 is a transmembrane protein localized in the trans-Golgi network, late endosomes, and notably in the pre-autophagosomal membrane. One function of mAtg9 could be the recruitment of the membrane lipids and proteins necessary for the elongation step (Atg12-Atg5 and LC3-PE) (Webber and others 2007).

Most proteins involved in the biogenesis of autophagosomes are removed from the autophagosome once it has been fully formed, probably to be recycled for subsequent use (Reggiori and others 2004; Legakis and others 2007). For this reason, autophagosome-specific proteins are few. The best known is LC3-II, which is the most widely used marker for revealing the presence of autophagosomes (Kabeya and others 2000).

Once the autophagosome has been fully formed, it can fuse with a lysosome. In mammals, the fusion process is complex and requires a series of maturation steps before the autophagosome can be transported to the lysosome. Little is known of these steps, but the microtubules seem to play a role (Webb and others 2004). The proteins necessary for fusion include proteins involved in other types of transport: vesicular proteins such as certain GTPases (Rab22, Rab24, Rab7), soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor activating protein receptor (SNARE) proteins, and the protein NSF (N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive fusion protein) (Wang CW and Klionsky 2003). Once the fusion has occurred, the acidic environment of the lysosome permits the autophagosome to be degraded by lysosomal enzymes, thus producing degradation products that can be recycled for protein synthesis and energy production.

Because the rest of this review addresses the effects of changes in autophagy, it is important to realize that a change in the number of autophagosomes is not on its own an unambiguous indicator of the level of autophagy. For example, the increased abundance of autophagosomes in Alzheimer disease has been shown to be the result of a defect in the fusion of autophagosomes to lysosomes (Nixon 2007). Various approaches are available to resolve this ambiguity. In experiments in vitro, it is usually possible to measure the rate of autophagic flux (Klionsky and others 2008). In vivo this may be difficult, but if the numbers of autolysosomes as well as autophagosomes can be shown to have increased, this is an indication that autophagic flux has increased (Puyal and others 2009). Study of the degradation of specific autophagic substrate as p62/SQSTM1 (Pankiv and others 2007) and additional treatment with lysosomal inhibitors to see if the markers accumulate could be complementary strategies to validate an increase in autophagic flux.

sec.title: Autophagy in Chronic Neurodegenerative Diseases
sec.p: In healthy neurons, it is generally difficult to detect autophagosomes. One reason for this might be that neurons are privileged cells, strongly protected by their own adaptive mechanisms and by glial cells against stimuli that induce autophagy strongly in other systems (e.g., nutrient deprivation). But that does not mean that autophagy is unimportant to neurons. One reason for the rarity of autophagosomes in neurons could be that the process of autophagy is so efficient that few are needed in normal conditions (Nixon and others 2005). In the long term, autophagy is essential for neuronal health, and insufficient autophagy appears to be a contributing factor in chronic neurodegenerative diseases. Knockout mice lacking Atg5 or Atg7 specifically in neurons rapidly develop symptoms of neurodegenerative diseases, with the presence of inclusions in neurons (Komatsu and others 2006; Hara and others 2006). Moreover, basal autophagy is essential for maintaining axon homeostasis and morphology, and its loss of function leads to axonal swelling, followed by progressive neurodegeneration (Nishiyama and others 2007; Komatsu and others 2007).

sec.title: Neurodegenerative Diseases: The Consequences of Reduced Autophagy?
sec.p: These roles of autophagy are important in neurodegenerative disease development. A common characteristic of many neurodegenerative diseases is the accumulation of mutated or toxic proteins and their aggregation. These diseases are characterized by proteinopathies and include notably Parkinson disease (aggregates of α-synuclein), Huntington disease (aggregates of polyglutamine), Alzheimer disease (aggregates of the peptide β-amyloid resulting from a faulty cleavage of the protein APP [amyloid precursor protein]), tauopathies (aggregates of hyperphosphorylated protein tau), or bovine spongiform encephalopathies. In all these different illnesses, the presence of excessive numbers of autophagosomes and autolysosomes has been shown in degenerating neurons (Rubinsztein and others 2005). However, in these chronic neurodegenerative diseases, autophagy seems to play a protective role, degrading mutated or toxic proteins, and does not appear to be mediating cell death. In particular, the enhanced autophagy may be compensating for a deficiency in proteasome activity (Pandey and others 2007). An Alzheimer-related mutation of presenilin-1 has been shown to cause a deficiency in autophagic clearance and may be the cause of pathogenic protein accumulations and neuronal cell death in Alzheimer disease (Lee and others 2010). Mutation of the protein Parkin, which is recruited to dysfunctional mitochondria and involved in the signal for mitophagy (selective degradation of mitochondria by autophagy), has been implicated in the pathogenesis of Parkinson disease (Narendra and others 2008).

sec.title: Stimulating Autophagy to Prevent Neurodegeneration?
sec.p: The use of pharmacological agents modifying autophagy has tended to confirm its protective role in neurodegenerative diseases associated with proteinopathies. Thus, inhibitors of autophagy such as 3-methyladenine (3-MA) or bafilomycin A1 diminish the degradation of aggregates, whereas inductors of autophagy such as rapamycin increase their elimination and reduce their toxicity (Ravikumar and others 2002; Webb and others 2003). A good example is Huntington disease, which is characterized by the abnormal production of polyQ polymers due to a mutation of the gene encoding the protein huntingtin and their accumulation in the form of insoluble aggregates. Not only does rapamycin treatment attenuate the toxicity of polyQ in cell culture models, but in some animal models of Huntington disease involving the overexpression of polyQ, it prevents neurodegeneration and enhances behavioral performance (Ravikumar and others 2004). More recently, it has been shown that stimulation of lysosomal cathepsin activities in the Alzheimer mouse model TgCRND8 can decrease extracellular amyloid deposition and prevent deficits in learning and memory (Yang DS and others 2011).

Thus, the stimulation of autophagy seems to be a promising neuroprotective strategy for neurodegenerative diseases associated with proteinopathies, although it remains to be determined whether the optimal treatment will target early (autophagosomal), late (autolysosomal), or both stages of the autophagic process. Nevertheless, the treatment would need to be moderate because excessive autophagy can be destructive, as discussed below.

sec.title: Autophagy in Neuronal Death
sec.p: Despite the life-promoting roles of autophagy, it is also associated with cell death, and the term autophagic (or type 2) cell death is frequently used to refer to dying cells containing numerous autophagosomes and autolysosomes (many early studies showed only autolysosomes). This is frequently observed during embryonic development and is probably the most common type of cell death in insect metamorphosis (Clarke 1990), but autophagic features are also associated with many cases of pathological cell death ranging from heart failure (Wang ZV and others 2010) to the death of cancer cells due to chemotherapy (Yousefi and Simon 2009).

sec.title: Early Studies Relating Autophagy to Cell Death in Neurons
sec.p: Cell death with autophagic characteristics is also observed in neurons. It generally occurs when there is massive cell death in a particular region, whereas the cells die by apoptosis when they are scattered among other cells that do not die (Clarke 1990). Thus, neuronal death during metamorphosis has a strong autophagic component (Schweichel and Merker 1973; Clarke 1990). For example, Rohon-Beard cells in the spinal cords of frog tadpoles die by “autophagic cell death” (Lamborghini 1987).

In most vertebrates, the most pronounced phase of neuronal death occurs relatively late, when synaptic connections are being formed. During this period, the neurons are highly dependent on retrograde (and anterograde) neurotrophic support, and numerous studies of neuronal death in development have involved axotomy or other means of depriving neurons of retrograde support. In some cases, the resulting neuronal death had autophagic characteristics, but in many others, it clearly did not. Developmental maturity appears to be an important factor determining the type of neuronal death. Thus, the death of axotomized motoneurons in larval frogs was found to have a “pyknotic” (apoptosis-like) morphology when the axotomy was performed in very young tadpoles, whereas very late axotomy caused classic chromatolysis. But axotomy at an intermediate stage caused the “genesis of numerous secondary lysosomes in degenerating cells”—in other words, cell death with an autophagic morphology (Decker 1978). Studies in chick embryos on the isthmo-optic nucleus, which is the source of the brain’s centrifugal projection to the retina in birds, showed an age dependence that was similar to the above but not quite so clear-cut (Clarke and Hornung 1989).

The above examples of autophagic responses in dying neurons suggested that autophagy might play a role in mediating the cell death, but this needs to be demonstrated by testing the effects of autophagy inhibition. Many of these experiments used nonneuronal cells, especially cell lines, and we need to take these into account.

sec.title: Autophagy as a Mediator of Cell Death
sec.p: There are three principal morphological types of cell death: type 1 or apoptosis, type 2 or autophagic cell death, and type 3, which includes several subtypes of which the best known is necrosis (Clarke 1990). The term autophagic cell death refers to a type of programmed cell death that is morphologically different from apoptosis, being characterized by the presence of numerous autophagosomes and autolysosomes, as has been described in many cell types, including neurons, during brain development (Schweichel and Merker 1973; Clarke 1990). It involves the destruction of organelles in autolysosomes. The cytoskeleton (Bursch and others 2000) and nucleus are initially preserved, but ultimately even the nucleus is sometimes found to be destroyed in lysosomes (Clarke 1990; Gonzalez-Martin and others 1992).

The presence of autophagic features in dying cells has been variously interpreted to reflect a death-mediating role of autophagy or, conversely, an attempt by the cell to protect itself against the death-mediating stimulus. Even in recent years, the death-mediating role of autophagy remains contested by some (Kroemer and Levine 2008). The fact that autophagy in dying cells often destroys a considerable part of the cell, including sometimes the nucleus, was long ago interpreted to indicate that autophagy must be death promoting (Hornung and others 1989; Clarke 1990). This interpretation was supported by numerous reports since 1992 of autophagy inhibition using 3-methyladenine and related inhibitors that were protective against cell death in numerous situations where it was characterized by an autophagic morphology (Sandvig and van Deurs 1992; Xue and others 1999), but the interpretation was clouded by the fact that the inhibitors were not specific for autophagy. The inhibition of autophagy by 3-methyladenine is due to its inhibition of phosphoinositide 3–kinase (PI3K) (Blommaart and others 1997), including the class III PI3K (VPS34), which is necessary for autophagy; more specific PI3K inhibitors such as LY294002 likewise inhibit autophagic cell death (Guillon-Munos and others 2005). But none of these PI3K inhibitors is specific for autophagy, partly because they inhibit the class I family of PI3Ks as well as the class III, as has recently been confirmed for 3-methyladenine (Wu and others 2010). Conclusive evidence for a death-mediating role of the autophagy required more specific inhibition, necessitating molecular techniques.

The first molecular confirmations that autophagy can be directly responsible for cell death were provided in 2004 by two studies employing RNA interference for the knockdown of autophagy genes (Atg5, 6, or 7) in cells incapable of undergoing apoptosis. In one of these studies, fibroblasts genetically modified so as to be unable to express proapoptotic Bax and Bak underwent cell death dependent on autophagy genes Atg5 and Beclin 1 when they were exposed to apoptotic inductors (Shimizu and others 2004). In the other study, the pharmacological inhibition of caspases, particularly proapoptotic caspase-8, led to programmed cell death that could be blocked by the knockdown of Atg7 and Beclin 1 (Yu and others 2004). Thus, when apoptosis is disactivated, cells can die by a purely autophagic death pathway.

Kroemer and Levine (2008) have objected that the use of apoptosis-incompetent cells is a too artificial situation for its results to be extended to practically relevant situations where apoptosis is functional, but numerous recent studies have confirmed that the knockdown of atg5, atg6, or atg7 is protective against cell death in many conditions and cell types, including cells either competent or incompetent for apoptosis (Chen and others 2008; Yousefi and Simon 2009; Kandouz and others 2010). Kroemer and Levine have also argued that the use of siRNA-mediated knockdown of atg genes may not be sufficiently specific for valid interpretation, but resistance to cell death has also been obtained in mice with cell-specific deletion of atg5 or atg7 or in embryonic fibroblasts from these mice (Wan and others 2008). This is true also in neurons (Uchiyama and others 2009), as discussed in more detail below. Thus, there is now considerable evidence that autophagic pathways can mediate cell death in practically relevant situations.

But even if this is accepted, the detailed mechanism is still unclear. Is autophagic digestion in autolysosomes the death-mediating event, or does an earlier stage of autophagy kill by pathways independent of lysosomes? If intralysosomal digestion is responsible, does it kill by devouring a large portion of the cell (Clarke 1990) or by destroying a particular cellular defense system, such as the antioxidant system (Yu and others 2006), or in other ways? Alternatively, lysosomes might kill by a process distinct from autophagy sensu stricto, such as lysosomal permeabilization, leading to the release of hydrolytic enzymes as has been claimed in various situations, including recently a model of Parkinson disease (Dehay and others 2010). These questions remain open in most models.

A further complication for understanding the role of autophagy in cell death is that several death pathways may be activated in the same cell. In such cases, even if autophagy has been shown to be death mediating, it cannot immediately be assumed that cell death is of the autophagic type because autophagy can in some cases trigger apoptosis. The ambiguity is due to the fact that apoptosis and autophagy are regulated by common mediators, and the activation of one can modify the other (Maiuri and others 2007). This question is discussed in more detail below, in the context of excitotoxicity and cerebral ischemia.

sec.title: Autophagy in Excitotoxicity and Acute Neural Disorders
Activation of Autophagy in Conditions Involving Excitotoxicity
sec.p: Excitotoxicity, a phenomenon induced by excessive stimulation, usually by the overactivation of excitatory amino acid (glutamate) receptors, is the main mediator of neuronal death in numerous pathologies of the nervous system, including cerebral ischemia and traumatic brain injury. The induction of autophagy has been shown in several acute excitotoxicity models, including the application of N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) onto organotypic hippocampal slices (Borsello and others 2003) and the direct in vivo injection of kainate into the brains of mice (Shacka and others 2007). Autophagy has also been reported in chronic excitotoxicity models, notably in the lurcher mouse, in which cerebellar Purkinje cells undergo constitutive depolarization (Yue and others 2002). However, the depolarization appears not to be the sole cause of the pathology (Selimi and others 2003), and the induced autophagy appears not to mediate the cell death in the lurcher (Nishiyama and others 2010).

An increase in Beclin 1 expression has been described in traumatic brain (Erlich and others 2006) and spinal cord injuries (Kanno and others 2009). In the cerebral cortex, traumatic brain injury has been shown to induce the translocation of Beclin 1 out of membrane microdomains containing NMDA receptor subunit NR2B and PSD95, with resultant stimulation of autophagy (Bigford and others 2009).

The first study showing an activation of autophagy after cerebral ischemia was that by Nitatori and colleagues (Nitatori and others 1995; Nitatori and others 1996), who detected by electron microscopy the presence of numerous autophagic vacuoles and an increase in the size of vesicles positive for cathepsin B in hippocampal CA1 neurons three days after ischemia. Several subsequent studies on cerebral ischemia have shown increases in the activation and expression of lysosomal proteases, increased expression of autophagosomal marker LC3-II, and increases in the numbers of morphologically identified autophagosomes (Seyfried and others 1997; Zhu and others 2005; Degterev and others 2005; Wen and others 2008; Puyal and others 2009). Similar changes are found in rodent neonatal cerebral hypoxia-ischemia, which is a model of perinatal asphyxia (Zhu and others 2005; Zhu and others 2006; Ginet and others 2009).

sec.title: Neuroprotection by Inhibition of Autophagy In Vivo
sec.p: Even though the activation of autophagy has been clarified in several excitotoxicity models, the role of autophagy in the associated neuronal death still needed to be defined for each pathological situation. Over the past three years, this has begun to be clarified by the inhibition of autophagy using pharmacological and molecular approaches.

Recent studies involving striatal injections of kainate (Wang Y and others 2008) or quinolate (Wang Y and others 2009) showed neuroprotection by 3-MA, suggesting a role of autophagy in mediating the neuronal death. However, apoptotic markers (p53, PUMA, Bax, caspase-3) were also reduced by 3-MA, raising questions about the relationship between autophagy and apoptosis in the mediation of the cerebral damage (Wang Y and others 2008).

Similar protection has been obtained with 3-MA in various focal cerebral ischemia models. Both in adult rats (Wen and others 2008) and in neonatal rats (Puyal and others 2009), focal ischemia enhanced morphological and biochemical markers of autophagy and lysosomal activation; in both models, 3-MA diminished all these effects and provided substantial neuroprotection. In the neonatal study, inhibition with 3-MA was also found to reduce several apoptotic markers (Fig. 3): activation of caspase-3 and caspase-9 and the translocation of apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) to the nucleus (Puyal and others 2009). However, inhibition of autophagy was proven to be a more promising strategy for postischemic neuroprotection than caspase inhibition, which failed to decrease the cerebral lesion.

sec.p: In view of the limited specificity of 3-MA, it is important to confirm the pharmacological results using more specific molecular methodologies. The most relevant studies for cerebral hypoxia-ischemia have focused on Atg7. Because the global deletion of atg7 is lethal soon after birth (Kuma and others 2004; Komatsu and others 2005), Koike and others (2008) resorted to the use of conditional knockout mice (Atg7flox/flox: nestin-Cre) in which atg7 is deleted specifically in CNS tissue. In a detailed study on neonatal hypoxia-ischemia (at P7), they characterized the activation of apoptotic (e.g., caspase-3) and autophagic pathways, showing, in particular, an increase in autophagosomal marker LC3-II and of autophagosomes/autolysosomes as identified by electron microscopy. Importantly, in these atg7 conditional knockout mice, the hippocampus was almost completely resistant to the hypoxia-ischemia, and caspase-3 activation was prevented.

Thus, the weight of evidence strongly supports the view that autophagy plays a pro-death role in acute neural disorders. This view was, however, challenged by Carloni and others (2008), who found that rapamycin (an inducer of autophagy) was neuroprotective in neonatal rats exposed to hypoxia-ischemia, whereas 3-MA did not affect the lesion size. However, the effects of these treatments on autophagy were verified only from their effect on Beclin 1 expression, which is not a direct measure of autophagy, and the dose of 3-MA injected by Carloni and others was eight times lower than the minimal effective dose for reducing the level of LC3-II when injected intracerebroventricularly in P12 rats (Puyal and others 2009) or adult rats (Wen and others 2008). Furthermore, rapamycin is an inhibitor of mTOR, which affects processes other than autophagy, notably cell growth and proliferation, and protein synthesis (Swiech and others 2008). For these above reasons, the results of Carloni and others do not demonstrate a pro-survival role of autophagy in neonatal hypoxia-ischemia, and complementary evidence is needed.

sec.title: Relationships between Autophagy and Apoptosis
sec.p: Research on cell lines indicates that apoptosis and autophagy are regulated by common mediators, and there are multiple routes for crosstalk between apoptotic and autophagic signaling pathways (Maiuri and others 2007). For instance, caspase-3 can inhibit autophagy by cleaving Beclin 1 (Luo and Rubinsztein 2010), and the knockdown of caspase-3 can induce cell death with autophagic characteristics (Bialik and others 2010), as can the inhibition of caspase-8 (Yu and others 2004). It has also been shown that a caspase-cleavage product of Atg5 can be translocated from the cytosol to mitochondria, where it interferes with the inhibitory action of Bcl-xL on Bax and hence triggers cytochrome c release and caspase activation (Yousefi and Simon 2009). It would be beyond our present scope to discuss this cell biological literature in detail, and we focus here on autophagy-apoptosis interactions in neurons.

In many cases of excitotoxicity, dying neurons expressed both apoptotic and autophagic features as following neonatal hypoxia-ischemia (Koike and others 2008; Ginet and others 2009). Moreover, the apoptotic and autophagic pathways appeared to interact. For example, several apoptotic markers were reduced by 3-MA in two studies (Wang Y and others 2008; Puyal and others 2009), and caspase-3 activation was prevented in the neuron-specific atg7 knockout mice in another study (Koike and others 2008). This raises the question whether the neuronal death mediated by autophagy is true autophagic cell death (independent of apoptosis) or whether it is autophagy-mediated apoptosis (Puyal and Clarke 2009).

Comparison of the cell death in two different brain regions suggests that both possibilities may be true, depending on the region. Ginet and others (2009) compared the process of neuronal death in hippocampal CA1 and CA3, as well as in the cerebral cortex, in a severe model of neonatal hypoxia-ischemia in P7 rats (Ginet and others 2009). In the cortex, the classical morphologies of pure autophagic (type II) or apoptotic (type I) cell death were never observed; the morphologies were always a mixture of the two. Nevertheless, neurons with strong autophagic activity showed only moderate apoptotic features: They showed only moderate chromatin condensation, were only sometimes positive for activated caspase-3 (more frequently near the center of the lesion), and were never positive for a DNA fragmentation assay (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling [TUNEL], which tends to show apoptotic neurons, although it is not rigorously specific). These observations are compatible with the interpretation that autophagy occurs upstream of apoptosis, and in a related neonatal model, focal cerebral ischemia at P12, inhibition of autophagy with 3-MA reduced apoptotic features (Puyal and others 2009).

In contrast, in the hippocampus, apoptosis and autophagy appeared to be segregated according to the hippocampal region. In CA1, the dying neurons had a frankly apoptotic (and partly necrotic) ultrastructure and were positive for caspase-3, whereas those in CA3 strongly expressed autophagic and lysosomal markers (punctate LC3, LAMP1, cathepsin D) and exhibited a strongly autophagic ultrastructure (Ginet and others 2009). This segregation indicates that neuronal apoptosis (or mixed apoptosis-necrosis) present in hypoxia-ischemia can occur without being triggered by autophagy and that neuronal death with strong autophagic features can be mediated without the need for caspase-dependent apoptosis (Fig. 4).

caption.p: Regional differences in the involvement of autophagy and apoptosis in mediating neuronal death in the lesioned hippocampus after neonatal hypoxia-ischemia. (A) LAMP1 immunolabeling is strongly increased in CA3, whereas (B) cleaved caspase-3 is restricted to CA1 and the dentate gyrus. Bars: 0.5 mm or 50 µm in high magnifications. (C) Electron micrographs of CA3 neurons at 24 hours show large numbers of autophagosomes in the cytosol. At higher magnification, note the presence of double-membrane structures encircling organelles (white arrowheads) and the presence of autolysosomes (black arrowheads). The nucleus (n) of such CA3 neurons shows very little, if any, chromatin condensation. Bar: 1 µm. (D) Electron micrographs of CA1 neurons at 24 hours after hypoxia ischemia show a hybrid phenotype of cell death with a mixture of necrotic and apoptotic features, including plasma membrane rupture, chromatin condensation in the nucleus (n), and swelling of organelles, as observed at high magnification. Bar: 1 µm. Adapted from Ginet and others (2009).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Autophagy is a physiological mechanism indispensable for correct development and for the health of neurons by its different roles in quality control for proteins and organelles and as an energy supplier (Fig. 5). The role of its induction in conditions of stress is, however, more complex because it can promote both health (in chronic neurodegenerative diseases) and neuronal death (in acute neural disorders). Thus, each brain pathology requires a specific study of the role played by autophagy. A better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of autophagy and elucidation of the relationship between autophagy and the different cell death pathways in neural disorders will enable autophagy to be manipulated appropriately (stimulation or inhibition) for therapeutic purposes.

caption.p: Paradoxical roles of autophagy in the nervous system. Basal (or constitutive) autophagy is a physiological process essential for the health of a neuron involved in the turnover of proteins and organelles. A decrease or a failure in basal autophagic activity can cause neurodegeneration. However, its induction can have paradoxical consequences, according to the nature of the stimuli, the intensity of the autophagic activity, and perhaps the context. Autophagy can contribute to cell survival (following deprivation of nutrients or pathogen invasion) or to cell death occurring naturally during development or pathologically (due to cerebral ischemia).
